In this paper, a two-dimensional M/MoS2 material system was constructed by supporting transition metal atoms M (M=Co, Ni, Cu) on the surface of MoS2. The structural properties, molecular adsorption and the reaction mechanism for water gas shift reaction (WGSR) were investigated based on DFT calculation. Compared with pristine MoS2, doping transition metal can make M/MoS2 more stable because the charge transfer between metal and MoS2 increases the polarization of Mo and S. The adsorption performance is significantly improved, which is conducive to the forward progress of the reaction. The band gap of materials is narrowed, which motivates MoS2 transforms to metal phase. The supporting metal can increase the charge transfer and the number of active sites in the system, which can effectively reduce the reaction energy barrier of WGS and improve the catalytic activity. The most potential WGSR mechanism of the three materials is the association mechanism, in which the HCOO* intermediate plays the leading role. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Water gas shift reaction (WGSR) Density functional theory (DFT), 2D material, Transition metal supporting Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Hydrogen energy is a kind of clean secondary energy sources with the greatest development potential in the 21st century. Water gas shift reaction (WGSR) H2O(g)+CO(g)=CO2(g)+H2(g), mainly used in the hydrogen production industry and synthetic ammonia industry [1,2]. Commercial WGSR catalysts are mainly divided into iron-based catalysts and copper-based catalysts, but they all have disadvantage of thermal sintering, sulfur and chloride poisoning [3,4]. Thus, preparing a high-efficiency catalyst to improve hydrogen production is an urgent problem to be solved. In recent years, by exfoliating layered two-dimensional (3D) precursors such as boron nitride, metal sulfides (such as MoS2, WS2), oxides and hydroxides, two-dimensional (2D) materials with different chemical properties have been synthesized [5]. As a new 2D material, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has become hot area due to their excellent anti-sintering, abundant natural resources and low price [6,7]. MoS2 commonly used for hydrogen production with excellent catalytic activity [8–10]. For example, Ding et al. [11] found that herein a series of transition metals (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) into the column−like superstructures with edge-terminated MoS2 nanosheet building blocks (termed as M−ET MoS2 SSs) is doped as the efficient catalysts for WGSR. 5%Ni−ET MoS2 SSs displaying the best average rate of 50.48 µmolH2gcat −1 s−1 in WGSR at 473 K, which is 4 and 13 times higher than those of the ET MoS2 SSs and commercial MoS2, respectively, and is even comparable to many noble-metal-based catalysts. A single‐atom Ru supported on MoS2 (SA‐Ru‐MoS2) electrocatalyst are prepared by Zhang et al. SA‐Ru‐MoS2 electrocatalyst exhibits a low overpotential of 76 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and the origin of high HER activity is mainly attributed to the synergy effects of single‐atom Ru doping and S vacancies [12]. However, the disadvantage of MoS2 is that its active site is at the edge and basal plane has no catalytic activity [13]. The key to solving this bottleneck lies in how to generate more effective active sites on inert surface of the MoS2, establish an effective electron transfer channel between the MoS2 surface and the CO and H2O molecules, and effectively transfer the large number of electrons to molecules. It has been reported that supporting transition metals is an effective way to use charge redistribution to increase the active sites on the catalyst surface. Studies have shown that transition metals supported on sulfides can significantly improve catalytic activity hydrogen production [14–16]. Copper [17], cobalt [18], and nickel-based [19] catalysts are widely used in WGSR with excellent activity. Cu-Fe3O4 catalysts are synthesized via an aerosol-spray self-assembly (ASSA) method by Yan et al. Study shows the Cu0.3Fe0.7Ox catalyst exhibits very high catalytic activity [20]. However, few research haves investigated transition metal MoS2 catalyzing WGSR. Therefore, transition metal M supporting MoS2 catalyst (M/MoS2, M=Co, Ni, Cu) was constructed in this paper. The Co, Ni, Cu atoms were used as a highly efficient active site and electron transfer channels, which effectively improved the electrons transfer ability to enhance CO and H2O molecules adsorption ability. Co, Ni, and Cu atoms make electron enrichment on a local scale to provide the driving force for CO and H2O redox. Computational details Calculation method All calculations in this paper were done under the Dmol3 in Material Studio 8.0, using electron exchange correlation potential and PBE functional based on generalized gradient (GGA), and considering spin polarization in the calculation [21,22]. The inner electrons of M/MoS2 (M=Co, Ni, Cu) are treated as frozen cores and replaced by effective nuclear potential pseudopotentials (ECP). The valence electron wave function is expanded by a dual-value basis set plus polarization function (DNP). The appropriate 4 × 4 × 1 k-point grids are adopted to sample the reciprocal space using the Monkhorst-Pack method. The Methfessel-paxton smearing is set to 5.0 × 10−3 Ha, and the accuracy is set to customized during the calculation process. The structural optimization is based on the energy difference less than 1 × 10−6 Ha, the atomic displacement less than 5.0 × 10−4 nm, and the convergence of the forces on each atom 2.0 × 10−3 Ha·Å−1 as criteria. The nine active species of CO*, H2O*, OH*, H*, O*, COOH* (cis-COOH*, trans-COOH*), CO2*, H2*, and HCOO* have optimized bond lengths and energies in accordance with literatures [23]. The linear synchronous transit (LST)/quadratic synchronous transit (QST) method are employed to search the minimum energy pathway and transition state (TS). Model construction Experimental methods such as chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [24] and mechanical exfoliation methods [25] can be used to prepare monolayer MoS2, and the experimental results also show that monolayer MoS2 has excellent catalytic activity [26]. Hence, we construct a MoS2 monolayer model. The one thickness layer is a 4 × 4 unit of MoS2 (001) surface, including 16 Mo atoms and 32 S atoms. The lattice parameters are a=12.64 Å, b=12.64 Å, and c=18.17 Å. The slab layer is simulated by periodically repeating enough symmetrical slabs. To avoid interaction between the adsorption and the bottom layer, we perform enough periodic repetitions and introduce a 15 Å thick vacuum layer in the z-direction. In this article, we use the M/MoS2 (M=Co, Ni, Cu) (001) surface as a model of active phase to research all WGSR steps. The top and side views of the surface are shown in Fig. 1 . Results and discussion Structural stability analysis The structural parameters of pristine MoS2 and metal modified MoS2 were analyzed and the results are shown in Table 1 . It indicates that the Mo-S bond length, interlayer height, S-Mo-S bond angle, and band gap of the original MoS2 are 2.42 Å, 3.17 Å, 81.70°and 2.11 eV, respectively, which are consistent with experimental and literature values [27,28]. After supporting metal, the Mo-S bond length is extended to 2.53, 2.52 and 2.47 Å, but the S-Mo-S bond angle and the interlayer height (h) do not change much. Thus, supporting metal does not cause a major change in the structure of MoS2. The metal forms metal-sulfur bonds with three surrounding sulfur atoms (Fig. 1), and the average bond length is 2.12 Å, 2.13 Å and 2.41 Å, respectively. According to the difference charge density (Fig. 2 ) and Mulliken population analysis (Table 1), it can be seen the charge transfer is from metal to sulfur, and finally transferred 0.21 e, 0.03 e and 0.05 e, which is quite similar with the literature [29]. The charge transfer between metal and MoS2 increases the polarization of Mo and S. There is strong electrostatic interaction between metal and layer, which is conducive to enhancing stability of the system [30]. For judging the stability of M/MoS2, the building energy ( E b ) is calculated according to formula (1): (1) E b = − [ E ( M / M o S 2 ) − E ( M ) − E ( M o S 2 ) ] E(MoS2), E(M/MoS2) and E(M) represent the total energy of MoS2, metal modified MoS2 and metal atom, respectively. E b is one of the bases for judging structural stability [31,32], the larger the building energy value, the more stable the system [33,34]. Calculation result shows that after metal supporting, E b of three MoS2 is 5.16 eV, 4.58 eV and 3.79 eV, respectively. According to the data provided by Professor Leo Brewer [35], the cohesive energies of Co, Ni, and Cu are 4.39 eV, 4.44 eV, and 3.49 eV, respectively. They are all smaller than E b , so the metals will not agglomerate into clusters, but will be stably dispersed in surface of MoS2. There is no imaginary frequency in M/MoS2, which indicates the system of M/MoS2 is stable. Previous literature reports that MoS2 has phase transition from semiconductor (2H) to metal (1T) with the band gap decreases [36], while 1T phase MoS2 is catalytically active [37]. After supporting metal, the band gap of Co/MoS2, Ni/MoS2 and Cu/MoS2 are reduced from 2.11 eV to 1.35 eV, 1.60 eV and 1.63 eV, respectively (Table 1, Fig. S1), indicating that MoS2 changes from the semiconductor phase (2H phase) to the metal phase (1T phase), which is beneficial to improve the catalytic activity. It can be seen from the partial density of states (PDOS) (Figs. 3 and 4 ) that the metal states are mainly derived from the 3d orbitals of M and the 4d orbitals of Mo. The density of states in the range from −6 to −3 eV mainly comes from the 2p orbitals of S. The number of peaks at the same energy increased after supporting metals, indicating that orbital between the metal and MoS2 is hybridized, and there is strong interaction between them [38,39]. In line with research of Norskov et al. [40–42], the d-band center theory has important applications in predicting the electronic activity and adsorption energy of transition metal catalysts. According to formula (2), the d-band center ( ε d ) can be calculated and in formula (3), we can calculate the d-band width ( W d ) through the spin-up/spin-down electrons: (2) ε d = ∫ − ∞ + ∞ E ρ d ( E ) d E ∫ − ∞ + ∞ ρ d ( E ) d E (3) W d = ∫ − ∞ + ∞ E 2 ρ d ( E ) d E ∫ − ∞ + ∞ ρ d ( E ) d E where ρ d is the density of states projected onto the d-band of M or Mo. Table 2 displays the calculated data of ε d and W d . By calculating the value of the d-band center, we can preliminarily predict the activity of the catalyst. Calculation proves that with introduction of metal, the ε d of MoS2 moves to lower energy level, Cu/MoS2 has the smallest ε d , which is −3.70 eV. It indicates that the intermediate is easily converted into products [43,44], which is benefit to the positive progress of the reaction. Supporting metals also leads to the increase of W d of system, and the value of Cu/MoS2 is 4.75 eV at the maximum. In short, with the introduction of metals, electron transfer from metal to molybdenum disulfide. There is strong electrostatic interaction between metal and layer, and the hybridization between orbitals makes system more stable. Supporting metal promotes the transition of MoS2 from semiconductor phase to metal phase. ε d moves to lower energy level, which makes intermediates easier to be converted into products. Such results are good at the improvement of catalytic activity. Consequently, introduction of transition metals may improve the stability and catalytic activity. Adsorption configuration and energy analysis To explore the most stable adsorption structure on the surface of M/MoS2 in WGSR, different positions and directions were considered (Fig.S2), including parallel and vertical. Base of formula (4), the adsorption energy ( E a d s ) is calculated: (4) E a d s = E − E 1 − E 2 where E, E1 and E2 are the energy of the optimized structure with adsorption, the isolated adsorption and three types of MoS2 catalysts. The symbol and numerical value of E a d s can measure the possibility and strength of adsorption. The larger the value is, the more heat liberation is released and the more stable the adsorption system is formed [45–47]. Adsorption configurations were optimized, and the optimal configuration (Fig. 5 ) was obtained by comparing E a d s (Table 3 ). The frequency calculation shows that there is no imaginary frequency, indicating that the adsorptions can be stably adsorbed on M/MoS2 [48,49]. As shown in Fig. S3, H2O* is mainly parallelly adsorbed in with the O end on metal sites and form an M-O bond with bond lengths of 2.05, 2.08, and 2.09 Å, respectively (also shown in Table S1), while pristine MoS2 has not format bond. Compared with the original MoS2 (−0.21 eV), the E a d s of MoS2 are significantly increased, which are −1.15 eV, −1.08 eV, and −1.22 eV, respectively. After adsorption, the O-H bond length of H2O* does not change significantly, but the bond angles expanded from 102.8˚ to 105.3˚, 105.2˚, and 105.2˚. According to Fig. S3, the charge transfers between the metal and the O of H2O*. The above shows that for H2O*, the adsorption changes from physisorption to chemisorption. Fig. S4 is the most stable structures and charge density differences of CO*. It shows that CO* is vertically adsorbed to the metal site with C-terminus and forms bond. The bond lengths of chemical bond in three types of MoS2 are 1.78, 1.78, and 1.83 Å (Table S2). It can be seen from Fig. S4 that charges are transferred from metal to the C of CO* and accumulated on the C-O bond. To sum up, the adsorption changed from physisorption to chemisorption. It can be seen from Fig. 5 and Table S3 that CO2* is adsorbed on the metal site by the O end. The bond length and bond angle of CO2* have not change significantly, and the adsorption energies for M/MoS2 are −0.64 eV, −0.50 eV and −0.31 eV, respectively. Although the adsorption energy is obviously increased compared to MoS2 (−0.08 eV), but the value is still small, and the bond length and angle of CO2* have not changed evidently, indicating that CO2* is adsorbed still by physical adsorption. H2* parallelly adsorbs on the metal site, and forms two M-H bonds (Fig. S5), the bond lengths for Co/MoS2, Ni/MoS2 and Cu/MoS2 are 1.66, 1.67 and 1.79 Å, severally (Table S4). However, when adsorbed on pristine MoS2, H2* does not form bonds and the adsorption energy was only −0.03 eV. After adsorption, the bond length of the H-H bond elongates from 0.75 Å to 0.84, 0.82, and 0.79 Å. The adsorption energy was increased to −0.82 eV, −0.72 eV, and −0.31 eV, respectively. Fig. S5 also indicates the charge transfer between H2* and metal, which shows that H2* is chemically adsorbed on M/MoS2. Studies have shown that molecules are easily adsorbed on metal sites, which is in line with literature reports [50]. It can be seen from Table 3 that the adsorption energy is significantly improved after supporting, indicating that M/MoS2 can improve the adsorption capacity, which is benefit the forward progress. The adsorption energies of the H2* and CO2* are small, which is favorable for desorption. It can be seen from Fig. 5 that OH* is adsorbed on the surface with O end, which may be because the metal easily accepts the lone pair electrons of O. COOH* is adsorbed with cis configuration, possibly due to the easier formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which reduces energy. The stability of species on M/MoS2 is basically arranged in the order of Co/MoS2>Cu/MoS2>Ni/MoS2. Thus, the above results show that supporting metals can greatly improve the adsorption capacity of MoS2. Analysis of WGSR mechanism It is reported that hydrolysis and hydrogen dissociation are slow steps [3,51], so how to reduce the energy of breaking O-H bond and dissociating hydrogen to accelerate WGSR under mild conditions is the main difficulty in current industrial hydrogen production. The water-gas shift reaction usually involve redox mechanism and association mechanism [52]. Both mechanisms involve the steps of H2O* dissociation and hydrogen formation. H2O* is adsorbed on the catalyst surface in chemisorption manner before the decomposition reaction occurs, it makes O-H bond strength reduce. In the redox mechanism, OH* from water splitting further decomposed into O* and H*, and CO* and O* react to generate CO2*. In the associative mechanism, CO* and OH* react to HCOO* or COOH*, which are subsequently decomposed to CO2* and H*. We carried out frequency vibration analysis during the transition state search and determined that each transition state has only one imaginary frequency (Table S5), indicating that the transition state structure is stable. The specific reaction route is shown in Fig. 6 and the initial state(IS), transition state(TS) and final state(FS) structures diagrams of WGSR element steps on M/MoS2 and MoS2 are displayed in Figs. 7 and S6. H2O* and CO* were first adsorbed and activated on catalyst, the energy of system was reduced, then the activated H2O* broke an O-H bond to generate H *and OH*. OH* will continue to decompose or react with CO*. The energy barrier of the slowest step in the redox mechanism on Co/MoS2 surface is 1.98 eV while in the association mechanism is 0.35 eV. In the Ni/MoS2 system, the values are 1.31 eV and 0.65 eV, respectively. In the Cu/MoS2 system, the values are 1.68 eV and 1.04 eV, respectively. The difference in the energy barrier values of the redox mechanism and the association mechanism indicates that the associative mechanism is more favored on M/MoS2. Table 4 shows the specific reaction energy barriers and energies, and the values are in line with other literature research values [53,54]. From the data in Table 4, it can be seen that Δ Ea of CO* and OH* react to HCOO* is lower than generating COOH* in three materials, so it is more likely to generate HCOO* intermediate, which may be because HCOO* is more stable. It is consistent with the adsorption energy results. After that, HCOO* is decomposed into CO2* and H*. The active H* reacted with another H* to produce H2* and subsequently desorption, then the whole reaction path ends. The overall energy changes suggest that among the three materials, the WGS reaction proceeds more readily with associative mechanism. The energy barrier ( Δ Ea ) of the system at each step was plotted as a graph (Fig. 8 ), from Fig. 8 we can find that no matter which system, the step with the highest energy barrier in the association mechanism is in ER 6. This indicates that for metal-supported MoS2, the decomposition of HCOO* to CO2* is the rate-determining step of the whole reaction for metal-supported MoS2. Simultaneous calculations show that the Ea of the H2* formation on pristine MoS2 is 1.71 eV, which is higher than that of Ni/MoS2. The Ea of the remaining reactions are higher than those of the three modified materials, indicating that the two-dimensional structure system of MoS2 supported by transition metal can activate H2O* and CO*, reduce the reaction energy barrier and improve the WGS reaction efficiency. We speculate that this may because that supporting metal increases the charge transfer and the number of active sites [55]. Conclusion (1) In this paper, M/MoS2 (M=Co, Ni, Cu) was constructed by supporting transition metal M (M=Co, Ni, Cu) on the surface of MoS2. After adding metal, the structure did not change much. The formation energies of three materials are 5.16 eV, 4.58 eV and 3.79 eV, respectively. The orbital between the metal and MoS2 is hybridized, indicating that M/MoS2 has good stability. The band gap of M/MoS2 is reduced to 1.35 eV, 1.60 eV and 1.63 eV after introduction of metals, which promotes the transformation of MoS2 to metal phase, and is favorable for catalytic activity improvement. (2) In M/MoS2, electrons are transferred from metal to MoS2. M/MoS2 transfers 0.21 e, 0.03 e and 0.05 e, which increases the charge density of metal-sulfur bond. Supporting metals enhance the adsorption capacity of species and change from physical adsorption to chemical adsorption. Each species can be stably adsorbed on M/MoS2, and the adsorption energy of H2O* and CO2* are small, which is beneficial to desorption and accordingly accelerating the reaction rate. (3) The WGSR mechanism of the three materials is an association mechanism, and the HCOO* intermediate plays a leading role. We speculate that this may be related to the stability of HCOO*. The energy barrier value of the WGS reaction was significantly reduced after doping metal, this may be due to the increasing charge transfer and number of active sites. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a two-dimensional M/MoS2 material system was constructed by supporting transition metal atoms M (M=Co, Ni, Cu) on the surface of MoS2. The structural properties, molecular adsorption and the reaction mechanism for water gas shift reaction (WGSR) were investigated based on DFT calculation. Compared with pristine MoS2, doping transition metal can make M/MoS2 more stable because the charge transfer between metal and MoS2 increases the polarization of Mo and S. The adsorption performance is significantly improved, which is conducive to the forward progress of the reaction. The band gap of materials is narrowed, which motivates MoS2 transforms to metal phase. The supporting metal can increase the charge transfer and the number of active sites in the system, which can effectively reduce the reaction energy barrier of WGS and improve the catalytic activity. The most potential WGSR mechanism of the three materials is the association mechanism, in which the HCOO* intermediate plays the leading role.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on water gas shift mechanism on MoS2 supported single transition metal M (M=Co, Ni, Cu) catalysts

dcterms:subject.$: Density functional theory (DFT), 2D material, Transition metal supporting
